Singular instance Of Canine Sagaciiy.--
One the early settlers of this country, says
the Rochester Telegraph, having been IN
the practice of visiting Connecticut TOR a
number of years, on the annual return OF the
first of May, on which occasions, dog,
which he had brought with him on his first
removal in this state. was party in his So
journs This individual died about three
years back; since which the dog has regu-
larly perigrinated to his native state-that
land IF Pumpkins, beauty and happiness -
The first journey of this animal after the
death OF his master, caused serious appre-
tensions of his safety: in fact, he was given
as "gone dog" He, however. returned,
after an absence of about the same extent as
that of his masters visits. On the return
of the same season he again "took leave OF
absence" and has recently returned, much
travel worn and foot sore, from the same
pous pilgrimage, somewhat disaffected at
the derilection in politics, of his ''steady hab-
it, friends.

OisguceJW inhumanNy.--A horse was
lately discovered tied to a tree in an obscure
nook Of the lIoosick river. about half ia mile
below the village Of Schagticoke Point
Tine wretched animal had endured all the
miselies Of starvation. lie had gnawed the
bark of the tree to which he was fastened.
from the roots mp to as high as he could
reach; had consumed the grass and even
the turf within the range of his tsther, and
had at last died in agony. The wretch bv
whom he was placed there, must have lost
every spark OF human feeling. York

I DEAR FRIENDS,


| Having through Divine favor, peen per-
uitted to meet together, pursuant to adj

state Of our religious society was again

Goodness being sensihly cxtcndel over the

4 that came before Us, After solemn deliher-
alton, AMI a free Interchange OF sentiment,
it was with much uuanimity. agreed TO re
commend the following veiWs and PROPOSE
! tions for your serious consideration:
\ The principal objects Of our Religious AS
sociatian, are the public worship of God; the
edihca,ion aud comfort of each other; the
strengthening ni the weak, and the recovery
of those who have wandered from the way
Of peace and safety.


1t is only under the blessed influence Of





tanned Whenever any among lis, so far
forsakc this Fundamental frincNle oi our
Union, as TO act in spirit os strife and dis
cord. aud to oppose and condemn their
brethren who may conscieutiously differ
from them in opinion, they break the bond
OF Gospel fellowship, and, as far as their in
Nuence extends, Illustrate the d. sign of rclI-
gious society. II such, after the use OF prop
er means, cannot be reclaimed, the peace
and harmony, and welfare Of the body re-
qu're that ;hey should be separated from our
communion.


The Apostle, aware Of the evils arising
from Contention in religious communities,
warned his brethren against it, declaring that
"where envying and strife is, there is ceniu-
sion and every evil work." aud they were
exhorted to withdraw from every brother
who walked Slisorderly. And we know from
experience, that wherever this evil spirit
has appeared in any Of our meetings, weak
ness and jealousy, and divisions have been
introGuced; and that excellent order has
been sunverted which has not only preserv-
ed us in love and concord, but protected the
rights and privileges Of all our Members.


With deep concern and sorrow, we have
observed the introduction and increase ofthi.
desolatne spirit. II is now about five wear.
since II made its appearance in our hitherto
J. favored Society, so as to become a snbjec


OF general concern For some time it wa


mostly confined to individuals acting as Off


GERS in the Church In this stage of it's pro


gress its consequences were Rricvous. Som,


who became infected by it, disregardng tn,


wholesome order established BY our Yearl,


Meeting, which directs, in the first place
hrlpate labor with such as give cause O
). concern, and afterwards, that Iouth!y ilect


1neS should treat with Them, forn,rd comb


nations amongst themselves unauthorized
:, ny the Society and unk 1own to its Discipline
a Friends travelling in the Ministry with Ger


tifcates from their Monthly and Quarterl


Meetings, were interrupted in their labors


and in some instances publicly opposed il


our Meetings for Divine worship. They


and other faithful Friends in the Ministry
OF were unjustly charged with preaching inf


del doctrines, denying the Divinity Of Chris,


and undertaking the Scriptures; togethe
= 'fith divers other things, generally know
ic to you, and equally unfounded.
ID 1t was not long however, before the con
= tagien spread and made its appearance
ut some of our Meetings for Discipline, oper
at ing to the exercised Members Of the Socie
'd ty, scenes of the most painful nature. Mea.
a ures of party character were introduced
IS and the established order of society was ii
tn fringed. by CARRYING these mea .ures into ea
n ecution, against the Judgment and contrar
I'd to the voice of the larger parts of Friend
IL present.


of At length the infection, taking a wide
IL range, appeared in cur Yearly Meeting
a where its deplorable effects we're equal
on conspicuous. Means were recently TAX
rs therein to over-rule the greater part of II
I'd Representatives, and Clerk was impose
ed upon the Meeting, without their concurrenc


or consent. A Committee was then appoin
ed to visit the Quarterly and Monthly Nee
K ings without the unity of the Meeting, ar
us contrary to the solid sense and judgment
AK much the larger number Of the Membe
II; i'll attendance; and several important su

nd the disunity and discord prevalent in tn

.Aw EprsTLE TO FRIENDS

Mr.. Sprague's Address before the society
fcr the suppression of intemperance, on
Thursday evening. attracted a crowded au-
dience, and was heard with profound attcn-
tion. 1t was powerful appeal to the pat
riot, the philanthropist, and the Christian.
20 unite in the determination of the vice OF
intemperance. The appalling spectacles OF
man falling away from his glorious destiny.
and woman sinking from her angel character
Of tae young bowing their faces in the oeau-
~ of their promise, and the grey headed
seeking the tomb in disgrace, we're present
ed in warm and glowing colours. and the du-
~ OF exerton to arrest the progress OF the
destroyer--by example as well as by pre-
cept-was enforced in strong and vigorous
language. The power of example, Mr.
Sprague contended, was the power on which
the society must chiefly rely for success in
their labors; as laws for suppressing dram
shops and laying heavy duties on imported
or domestic liquors, could be of little avail,
SO long as custom authorizes, and renders
almost indispensable, the constant use OF ar
dent spirits, wines and cordials, on all occa-
sions of hospitality OF festivity. The revolt
ing portraits he sketched of the son, the hus-
band, and the wife, given over to the om-
nipotent despotism of strong drink, It is fear
ed, are not the creation of a poetical ina
gination, but the two faithful pictures OF
painful and frequent realities. He traced
the all-pervading propensity to dangerous
indulgence through all classes OF society
from the rich, who boast Of their wine that
has been rocked upon the ocean and rlpen-
ed beneath an Indian sun, to the miserable
tenants of the hovel, who will have rum,
though their children famsh for lack OF
bread; and urged to the necessity of com
mencing the reformation so much desired
among the rich and fashionable.


After touching upon many OF the evils ot
iitemperance. as they affect man in the life
that is, the orator alluded to the unspedkable
Importance they assumed, when man was
considered as a being born to live forever
Time would cool the hot blood of youth. and
Philosophy might take the reigns that pas
sion resigned, but the vampire lntenper.
ance would cling closer as it drew Its cap
tive nearer to the grave. Is it not wonder
full, Che sad) that a creature glowing wits
the divinity of his Creator-cndowea with
energies TO control the things Of one world,
and with attributes that capacitate him Tor
the joys of another--abe to bind to his will
the elements that surround him, making
the winds and the waters the ministers OF
his pleasure--riffling the caverns OF the
earth of their unsunned MISUNDERSTANDING



places-exploring TIL unbounaed realms OF
creation till he stands in speechleSs
homage at the footstool of creations awful
Founder---is it not indeed wonderful, that
such a being, so rarely endowed, should
dare to quench the sacred fire that has de
scended upon him--cumberng the earth he
was born to subdue, and torfeitlns the Hea-
ven he was ordained 70 enjoyt


The orator adiured the clergy, the anont-
ed ministers Of Christ, who enjoyed the prl-
vilege and had the command to speak Il
men of their immortal destiny, TO aid II
the work Of reformation. fit were impor
sant Che said) TO make men beGere right
was it not still more important to max,
them do right. If it were their duty as min
listers to point the way to Heaven, was It no
their duty, to fit men for Heavens enjoy
ments. They could sharpen and burnisl
their weapons, and set themselves IN aTa'
against each other, in defence of their yari
Gus and contradictory creeds. and why coulc
they not unite their powers to overthrow
the giant sin that wars with every creed.


In conclusion, Mr.. Sprague cxhorted til
Society to persevere in their honorable la
bors, not suffering themselves to be dishcart
ened because they could not accomplish al
they wished. All human efforts The said
however laudable, must be marked by i'm
perfection. Thar is the badge of earth an
all that is earthly. 1t is hung round th
neck Of man, before his first repose on hi
mothers lap, and it remains there till hi
last sleep on the lap of the common mothe
of all. 1t is impossible entirely to root ou
drunkenness--but it may be made so rare


crime, that the guilty ones shall stand OF
like dark pillars on the road of life, to remin
the innocent how far they have left then be
hind. Go on, then, as YOU have begun. tn
health and happiness of individuals, ii
comfort of families, the welfare Of societ
call upon you. The fiery serpents of il
temperance are abroad in the land, let yol
example be the symbol OF healing, which III
afflicted may look up to and live. What !
say and do, others will initiate. Alread
there is rustling among the leaves Of II
forest, and it foretells the rising wind tn;
shali come in its parity to cleanse the sufft
eating atmosphere. Reformation is begin
ming at the right place, even in public opir
ion. Win but that, and it will do more I,
you, than all the laws that sumber in I.
dust of your public archieves Go on ar
may the prayers Of good men accompar
you, and the blessing of heaven seal yo,
honorable labors And when that hou
which must come TO us all, shall come to W
when lingering on the confines Of life al
death, the awed and subdued spirit looI
back to the scenes that have faded in Il
distance-when thr hollow applause Of IL

TIE Ruling Passion Strong in Death
The following interesting and characteristic
anecdotc, we were not before acquainted
with: it is related in the Brooklyn Star
Bonaparte's last falterng accents were about
his son at the head of an army. The great
American Patriot and Statesman, expressed
thoughts equally characte ,istic, but of a
different turn OF mind. According to Wirt's
oratlon, "Those who surrounded the death
bed OF Mr.. Jefferson, report, that in the in
tervals OF delirium that occurred, his mind
manifestly relapsed to the age of the revou-
ton, He talked, in broken sentences, OF
the Committee Of Safety. which he imagin-
ed to be still in action. One of his exclama
tions was-"Waln the committee to be OF
their guardl' and he instantly rose in hi.
bed, with the help of his attendants, and
went through the act Of writing a turriel
note.


Col Leavenworth passed through Frank
lin. Missouri, on the 29th of April. on hi
way to the River Platte, to examine and Fl,
on situation for a military cantonment
and on the first of May four companies of u
S. troops arrived at Franklin by water, an'
proceeded OF to join lin.

Dear Boots--A Mr. Eastman, of Boston,
paid $1,000 as the penalty for imprisoning a
French gentleman, and putting him in irons.
r. was boarder in tavern in Boston where
the Frenchman lodged; the latter, on his
departure, called for his boots, of which he
had two pair; put on one pair, and the 9TH
er into valise, and set off Eastman miss
ed his boots, and found ansther pair instead,
he pursued and overlook the Frenchman in
New Hampshire, handcuffed him, conveyed
him to Boston, and lodged him in Jail over
sunday. On examination, it appeared that
the boots in the valse were Eastman's, and
were handed to the other man by mistake.
The court liberated him, and he brought an
action for damages which has been settled
20 saoye.

amongst US with deep concern and exercise
patiently waiting in the hope, that time aho
reflection would convince cur brethren OF
the inpropriety of such course and that,
being favored to see the evil consequences
of such conduct, they might retrace their
steps. But, hitherto, we have waited IN vain.
Time and opportunity tor reflection have
been amply afforded, but have not produced
these desirable results On the contrary,
the spirit OF dscord and confusion has gained
strength; and to us there now appears no
way TO regain the harmony and tranquility
of the body, but by Withdrawing ourselves
not from the Society OF Friends, nor from
the exercise of its salutary Discipline-but
from religious communion with those who
have introduced, and seem disposed to con-
tlnue, such disorders amongst us.


The quiet and solemnity of our Meetings
for Divine Worshp-thc blessings OF Cos
pie Ministry unshackled by human authori
ty-the preservation Of our religious liberty
the advancement of our Christian testimo-
nes--and the prosperity of Truth, so far as
il IS connected with our labors, we believe,
very much depend upon the early adoption
of this measure.


We therefore, under solemn and weigh





and with arden. desires that all our move

Iearly Meeting held in Philadelphia; for

ty-to exaIt the standard Of Truth--pro-

MRS. Ciarissa Iler died in Neville, anoet
80 miles from the city of Cincinnati, on the
18th April. Her death was supposedto De
caused by fright As she was sitting at
home in the evening, a young man impru-
IDENTIFY wrapped himself in white sheet
and came into the house. Mrs. Her beng
in delicate state of health, the fright
brought on an illness, from which she never
recovered

.NrTy Gold Mne.--A letter now before US
from Taxahaw, Lancaster District, dated
23d ult. states that the richest gold mine in
the Southern States has lately been discov-
cred in the neghbourhood of that place.
Seven hands from N Carolina are now en-
ployed in the mine. The prospect is highly
promising and our correspondent says -
Before long you will see our Lancaster
farmers coming to market with gold instead
Of cotton;"--hepe some of our subscribers
live near this place CherasV Shec.

Nothing is talked of at Frankfort, but the
will Of the late Mr.. Bethmann, who has left
fortune of twenty million of francs Dur
ing the whole course of his life he was ex-
tremely successful and yet his widow is in
situation difficult to be described. BY this
will Mrs. Bcthmann receives only an annuity
sufficient for her support, while lady to
whom the banker was attached is provided
for like the mistress of a Prince. The wid-
ow, by this will, is to leave the house of her
husband, within year, to renounce all right
to the education of her children, and to give
up, as part of her entaled estate, all her
Jewels and valuable effects.-BruSSeis Pa.

IN extraordinary surgical oherati0n.-A
tumor weighing upwards OF eight pounds.
larger in size than the human head, was ex.
tracted entire from the abdomen of a wo.
man in London, on the 21st of March, by DR..
Granville. withstanding the extent of
the incisisn. such was the facility with
which the operation was conducted, that
the quantity OF blood lost did not exceed two
ounces.

The singular Phenomenon described in the
following article from the Lexington, Kentucky,
Gazette, OF the 25th ult. was witnessed in other
parts Of Kentucky, and aiso in Washington CITY


"Corona or WliO,-The most luminous phc-
nomena of this kind we rccollcct ever to have
seen, WIS visible yesterday morning. Three
circles appeared, the first was noticed about s
O'Clock, and continued several hours. 1t was
the smallest and most brilliant, and more than
twenty degrees in diameter. 1t exhibited most
OF the prsmatic colors, nearly as bright as in the
rainbow,ln which red and yellow were prcdonn-
ant The outer or largest circle was about sixty de-
grees in diameter, the colors in which were not
so brilliant as those in the smaller one, and re-
sembled the pale fame of candle. The third or
middle one, was barely visible. The uncom-
mon b!illlancy of those Coronas, together with
the appearance of three at the same time, cir
cumstance not recollected by many to have hap
pened before alarmed several who had never read
or thought much on the causes which produce
the rainbow, or on the various phenomena pro.
dnced by the reflection and refraction of LIGHT.
Many were OF the opinion that it was ominous of
some extraordinary event about to happen. con.
sequently inquiries were made of the aged and


learned, the probable cause Of this uncommon
appearance"

Femate Craeity,-A lady so played upon
the feelings of young gentleman, who court
cd her as to break his heart. and he re-
quested on his dying bed. that it might be
embalmcd and taken to her as his last gift,
and without her being acquainted with it,
When brought to her, She seemed amazed,
but on recollecting herself, called her maid
and smiling said. Fanny. take it up stairs,
and place it on my toilette l want pin
cushion"

Sir Joshua Reynolds never inscribed even
his initials on any of his pictures; two excep-
tions, however, we can oppose to his nSn
ScrIhsn habit. One in the sublime persons
ficaton of Mrs. Siddons as the Tragic
MISE, wherein he has inscribed his name at
length on the lower border OF her spreading
robe. The lady on beholding this departure
from his custom, observed, e,r cathedrd, with
solemn dignity, 20. Sir Joshua, this is too
much" To which the gallant knight re-
pled-"Madam, | thus seek immortal fame
on the hem of your garment"


Neither so gallant nor polite was the OBJ
servation of Major B.s*s'', the old bache-

"Fatai Revenge. "A man by the name
OF Prlce, has been convicted in Sussex coun-
ty, N. j. OF the crime of arson, for burning
the barn of Mr.. Nicholas Ryerson, last win.
ter. He was sentenced to undergo ten wears
imprisonment. Upwards of eighty witnesses
were examined, and the trial occupied the
better part of five days. Price is man Of
handsome fortune, and was led to the com
mission of the crime Of which he has been
convicted by a spirit of revenge

full articles.article:
Singular instance Of Canine Sagaciiy.--
One the early settlers of this country, says
the Rochester Telegraph, having been IN
the practice of visiting Connecticut TOR a
number of years, on the annual return OF the
first of May, on which occasions, dog,
which he had brought with him on his first
removal in this state. was party in his So
journs This individual died about three
years back; since which the dog has regu-
larly perigrinated to his native state-that
land IF Pumpkins, beauty and happiness -
The first journey of this animal after the
death OF his master, caused serious appre-
tensions of his safety: in fact, he was given
as "gone dog" He, however. returned,
after an absence of about the same extent as
that of his masters visits. On the return
of the same season he again "took leave OF
absence" and has recently returned, much
travel worn and foot sore, from the same
pous pilgrimage, somewhat disaffected at
the derilection in politics, of his ''steady hab-
it, friends.

full articles.headline:
WILLIAM GIBBONS, , a.,


HENJ. FERRIS, o'' -
full articles.article:
OisguceJW inhumanNy.--A horse was
lately discovered tied to a tree in an obscure
nook Of the lIoosick river. about half ia mile
below the village Of Schagticoke Point
Tine wretched animal had endured all the
miselies Of starvation. lie had gnawed the
bark of the tree to which he was fastened.
from the roots mp to as high as he could
reach; had consumed the grass and even
the turf within the range of his tsther, and
had at last died in agony. The wretch bv
whom he was placed there, must have lost
every spark OF human feeling. York
SiQEesn!GH.

full articles.headline: From the .Saturdav Evening Poss.
full articles.article:
According to promises made in oar last
No. we now present the exposition Of the
state Of the Society of Friends, as produced
at their last Conf-rence--it is signed by a
Committee ofthe highest rcspectability, in
each Of the Quarterly Meetings which com
nose the yearly Meeting.

In late number of the London Courier it
is stated, that the insolyent debtors court
had been that morning unusually crowded,
"mainly on account OF hearing the examina-
ton of VIM. Benbow, who is opposed by his
creditros for not having inserted in his sche-
dule the bones of Thomas Paine. which il
is said he has now in a cellar in his horse

The drawing Of the Georgia Land Lottery,
closed on the 25th ult, The tract of land sup.
posed 10 be most valuable in the new Territory,
remained iii tie wheel until the days drawing
preceding the tPt, and WAS drawn by female
idiot of Columbia county. No 81, in the 2lst
district of Muscogcc, was the number that drew
this prize, On the morning Of that day, the
spectators were the tip-toc Of expectation for
the drawing OF this NO, and a No. 81 being an.
nounccd (wthont noticing the district one OF
these gentry, who knew Revolutionary soldier
in Jefferson county held ticket Of this number,
leaped on his horse and rode 65 mlcsin fire hours
to carry the news, and before the error was de.
tected (for this M. 81 was in another district)
he hal purchased the land, and paid down a
part otthc purchase m ncy. On the mistake be.


ing made known, the old soldier refunded the
money, and the spcculatcr had his ride jGy ais
pains

full articles.headline: .Aw EprsTLE TO FRIENDS
full articles.article:
A;T E7pTSTLE TO FRIENDS


OfMe Qaarieriy aad Monthly Meeting,
Within the compass of the Yearly meeting


held in Philadelphia; Adopted 1t a Cen


cral Meeting of Friends At Green street
Meeting House, in that City, by adjourn
mcuts on the 4th aul 5th of the 9th Nc.
1897.


I DEAR FRIENDS,


| Having through Divine favor, peen per-
uitted to meet together, pursuant to adj
iouinment in the fourth month last, the
state Of our religious society was again
! br9ugh, into view The wing Of Ancient
Goodness being sensihly cxtcndel over the
several sittings Of the Meeting, we have
been enabled TO consider the subjects
4 that came before Us, After solemn deliher-
alton, AMI a free Interchange OF sentiment,
it was with much uuanimity. agreed TO re
commend the following veiWs and PROPOSE
! tions for your serious consideration:
\ The principal objects Of our Religious AS
sociatian, are the public worship of God; the
edihca,ion aud comfort of each other; the
strengthening ni the weak, and the recovery
of those who have wandered from the way
Of peace and safety.


1t is only under the blessed influence Of





tanned Whenever any among lis, so far
forsakc this Fundamental frincNle oi our
Union, as TO act in spirit os strife and dis
cord. aud to oppose and condemn their
brethren who may conscieutiously differ
from them in opinion, they break the bond
OF Gospel fellowship, and, as far as their in
Nuence extends, Illustrate the d. sign of rclI-
gious society. II such, after the use OF prop
er means, cannot be reclaimed, the peace
and harmony, and welfare Of the body re-
qu're that ;hey should be separated from our
communion.


The Apostle, aware Of the evils arising
from Contention in religious communities,
warned his brethren against it, declaring that
"where envying and strife is, there is ceniu-
sion and every evil work." aud they were
exhorted to withdraw from every brother
who walked Slisorderly. And we know from
experience, that wherever this evil spirit
has appeared in any Of our meetings, weak
ness and jealousy, and divisions have been
introGuced; and that excellent order has
been sunverted which has not only preserv-
ed us in love and concord, but protected the
rights and privileges Of all our Members.


With deep concern and sorrow, we have
observed the introduction and increase ofthi.
desolatne spirit. II is now about five wear.
since II made its appearance in our hitherto
J. favored Society, so as to become a snbjec


OF general concern For some time it wa


mostly confined to individuals acting as Off


GERS in the Church In this stage of it's pro


gress its consequences were Rricvous. Som,


who became infected by it, disregardng tn,


wholesome order established BY our Yearl,


Meeting, which directs, in the first place
hrlpate labor with such as give cause O
). concern, and afterwards, that Iouth!y ilect


1neS should treat with Them, forn,rd comb


nations amongst themselves unauthorized
:, ny the Society and unk 1own to its Discipline
a Friends travelling in the Ministry with Ger


tifcates from their Monthly and Quarterl


Meetings, were interrupted in their labors


and in some instances publicly opposed il


our Meetings for Divine worship. They


and other faithful Friends in the Ministry
OF were unjustly charged with preaching inf


del doctrines, denying the Divinity Of Chris,


and undertaking the Scriptures; togethe
= 'fith divers other things, generally know
ic to you, and equally unfounded.
ID 1t was not long however, before the con
= tagien spread and made its appearance
ut some of our Meetings for Discipline, oper
at ing to the exercised Members Of the Socie
'd ty, scenes of the most painful nature. Mea.
a ures of party character were introduced
IS and the established order of society was ii
tn fringed. by CARRYING these mea .ures into ea
n ecution, against the Judgment and contrar
I'd to the voice of the larger parts of Friend
IL present.


of At length the infection, taking a wide
IL range, appeared in cur Yearly Meeting
a where its deplorable effects we're equal
on conspicuous. Means were recently TAX
rs therein to over-rule the greater part of II
I'd Representatives, and Clerk was impose
ed upon the Meeting, without their concurrenc


or consent. A Committee was then appoin
ed to visit the Quarterly and Monthly Nee
K ings without the unity of the Meeting, ar
us contrary to the solid sense and judgment
AK much the larger number Of the Membe
II; i'll attendance; and several important su
" jerts were necessarily dismissed. owing
nd the disunity and discord prevalent in tn


body.

full articles.headline:
INTENfPERANCE.

From the Boston Daily .4duertiser.
full articles.article:
Mr.. Sprague's Address before the society
fcr the suppression of intemperance, on
Thursday evening. attracted a crowded au-
dience, and was heard with profound attcn-
tion. 1t was powerful appeal to the pat
riot, the philanthropist, and the Christian.
20 unite in the determination of the vice OF
intemperance. The appalling spectacles OF
man falling away from his glorious destiny.
and woman sinking from her angel character
Of tae young bowing their faces in the oeau-
~ of their promise, and the grey headed
seeking the tomb in disgrace, we're present
ed in warm and glowing colours. and the du-
~ OF exerton to arrest the progress OF the
destroyer--by example as well as by pre-
cept-was enforced in strong and vigorous
language. The power of example, Mr.
Sprague contended, was the power on which
the society must chiefly rely for success in
their labors; as laws for suppressing dram
shops and laying heavy duties on imported
or domestic liquors, could be of little avail,
SO long as custom authorizes, and renders
almost indispensable, the constant use OF ar
dent spirits, wines and cordials, on all occa-
sions of hospitality OF festivity. The revolt
ing portraits he sketched of the son, the hus-
band, and the wife, given over to the om-
nipotent despotism of strong drink, It is fear
ed, are not the creation of a poetical ina
gination, but the two faithful pictures OF
painful and frequent realities. He traced
the all-pervading propensity to dangerous
indulgence through all classes OF society
from the rich, who boast Of their wine that
has been rocked upon the ocean and rlpen-
ed beneath an Indian sun, to the miserable
tenants of the hovel, who will have rum,
though their children famsh for lack OF
bread; and urged to the necessity of com
mencing the reformation so much desired
among the rich and fashionable.


After touching upon many OF the evils ot
iitemperance. as they affect man in the life
that is, the orator alluded to the unspedkable
Importance they assumed, when man was
considered as a being born to live forever
Time would cool the hot blood of youth. and
Philosophy might take the reigns that pas
sion resigned, but the vampire lntenper.
ance would cling closer as it drew Its cap
tive nearer to the grave. Is it not wonder
full, Che sad) that a creature glowing wits
the divinity of his Creator-cndowea with
energies TO control the things Of one world,
and with attributes that capacitate him Tor
the joys of another--abe to bind to his will
the elements that surround him, making
the winds and the waters the ministers OF
his pleasure--riffling the caverns OF the
earth of their unsunned MISUNDERSTANDING



places-exploring TIL unbounaed realms OF
creation till he stands in speechleSs
homage at the footstool of creations awful
Founder---is it not indeed wonderful, that
such a being, so rarely endowed, should
dare to quench the sacred fire that has de
scended upon him--cumberng the earth he
was born to subdue, and torfeitlns the Hea-
ven he was ordained 70 enjoyt


The orator adiured the clergy, the anont-
ed ministers Of Christ, who enjoyed the prl-
vilege and had the command to speak Il
men of their immortal destiny, TO aid II
the work Of reformation. fit were impor
sant Che said) TO make men beGere right
was it not still more important to max,
them do right. If it were their duty as min
listers to point the way to Heaven, was It no
their duty, to fit men for Heavens enjoy
ments. They could sharpen and burnisl
their weapons, and set themselves IN aTa'
against each other, in defence of their yari
Gus and contradictory creeds. and why coulc
they not unite their powers to overthrow
the giant sin that wars with every creed.


In conclusion, Mr.. Sprague cxhorted til
Society to persevere in their honorable la
bors, not suffering themselves to be dishcart
ened because they could not accomplish al
they wished. All human efforts The said
however laudable, must be marked by i'm
perfection. Thar is the badge of earth an
all that is earthly. 1t is hung round th
neck Of man, before his first repose on hi
mothers lap, and it remains there till hi
last sleep on the lap of the common mothe
of all. 1t is impossible entirely to root ou
drunkenness--but it may be made so rare


crime, that the guilty ones shall stand OF
like dark pillars on the road of life, to remin
the innocent how far they have left then be
hind. Go on, then, as YOU have begun. tn
health and happiness of individuals, ii
comfort of families, the welfare Of societ
call upon you. The fiery serpents of il
temperance are abroad in the land, let yol
example be the symbol OF healing, which III
afflicted may look up to and live. What !
say and do, others will initiate. Alread
there is rustling among the leaves Of II
forest, and it foretells the rising wind tn;
shali come in its parity to cleanse the sufft
eating atmosphere. Reformation is begin
ming at the right place, even in public opir
ion. Win but that, and it will do more I,
you, than all the laws that sumber in I.
dust of your public archieves Go on ar
may the prayers Of good men accompar
you, and the blessing of heaven seal yo,
honorable labors And when that hou
which must come TO us all, shall come to W
when lingering on the confines Of life al
death, the awed and subdued spirit looI
back to the scenes that have faded in Il
distance-when thr hollow applause Of IL
raC tg-.pn -, Il -

TIE Ruling Passion Strong in Death
The following interesting and characteristic
anecdotc, we were not before acquainted
with: it is related in the Brooklyn Star
Bonaparte's last falterng accents were about
his son at the head of an army. The great
American Patriot and Statesman, expressed
thoughts equally characte ,istic, but of a
different turn OF mind. According to Wirt's
oratlon, "Those who surrounded the death
bed OF Mr.. Jefferson, report, that in the in
tervals OF delirium that occurred, his mind
manifestly relapsed to the age of the revou-
ton, He talked, in broken sentences, OF
the Committee Of Safety. which he imagin-
ed to be still in action. One of his exclama
tions was-"Waln the committee to be OF
their guardl' and he instantly rose in hi.
bed, with the help of his attendants, and
went through the act Of writing a turriel
note.


Col Leavenworth passed through Frank
lin. Missouri, on the 29th of April. on hi
way to the River Platte, to examine and Fl,
on situation for a military cantonment
and on the first of May four companies of u
S. troops arrived at Franklin by water, an'
proceeded OF to join lin.

Dear Boots--A Mr. Eastman, of Boston,
paid $1,000 as the penalty for imprisoning a
French gentleman, and putting him in irons.
r. was boarder in tavern in Boston where
the Frenchman lodged; the latter, on his
departure, called for his boots, of which he
had two pair; put on one pair, and the 9TH
er into valise, and set off Eastman miss
ed his boots, and found ansther pair instead,
he pursued and overlook the Frenchman in
New Hampshire, handcuffed him, conveyed
him to Boston, and lodged him in Jail over
sunday. On examination, it appeared that
the boots in the valse were Eastman's, and
were handed to the other man by mistake.
The court liberated him, and he brought an
action for damages which has been settled
20 saoye.

full articles.headline: Fran, he Truth Teller
full articles.article:
The London Times furnishes the following
choice morceatt, which the scholar and the man
of wit will alike relish, in allusion to the late
Cabinet Ministers of England. 1t was ascribed
to Thomas Moore, but this the Times denes.---
We have filed up the names, which, in the Eng.
lsh paper, were only designated by the initial
and final letters.

First ahhearancc fthe English in Chino


in Chinese typographical account Of
Canton, it is stated that I'm the winter Of
the 29th year of Wanlee (about looo) two
or three large ships came to Macoa; the
peoples clothes were red, their bodies tall
and their hair red. Their eyes were blue
and sunk into their heads; their teet were
one cubit two tenths long. they frightened
the people by their strange appearance
The English were not permitted to land
merely on account of the extraordinary fig
ure they cut; but on the 10th year of Shun-
che, their ambassadors were received, and
"the Emperor. in consideration Of the df-
fculty of the voyage, ordered them to come
once in eight years with tribute

full articles.headline: IX,-LoRn BrxLrY
full articles.article:
Thrice fortunate old man, 10 thce alone
The gricts which racked thy brethren arc un.


known.
While Melville's heart becomes heavier load
At every stage along the Northern road
While Eldon, tortured by patcrnal fears,
Counts the small savings Of iaborious years,
Plans secure escape from duns and gaols
To some cheap cot in Devon or in Wales,
And hopes BY frugal care, in that retreat,
With small assistance, TO make both ends meet,
Thou withunchanged etiulgence sill wilt shine,
Thine is the council, and the lcvrc thine;
Still shall thy heart beat higher the ray.
Which gilds the auspicious morn OF quarter day.
With that meek voice that wolld not scare a


mouse,
Still shalt thou lull the mufmur of the House,
In manner gentle as in matter bold,
Shalt prove old rags equivalent to gold,
Or for fresh measures Of dead weight shall call.
Thyself, Heaven knows, the deadcst weight Of


all

l.
amongst US with deep concern and exercise
patiently waiting in the hope, that time aho
reflection would convince cur brethren OF
the inpropriety of such course and that,
being favored to see the evil consequences
of such conduct, they might retrace their
steps. But, hitherto, we have waited IN vain.
Time and opportunity tor reflection have
been amply afforded, but have not produced
these desirable results On the contrary,
the spirit OF dscord and confusion has gained
strength; and to us there now appears no
way TO regain the harmony and tranquility
of the body, but by Withdrawing ourselves
not from the Society OF Friends, nor from
the exercise of its salutary Discipline-but
from religious communion with those who
have introduced, and seem disposed to con-
tlnue, such disorders amongst us.


The quiet and solemnity of our Meetings
for Divine Worshp-thc blessings OF Cos
pie Ministry unshackled by human authori
ty-the preservation Of our religious liberty
the advancement of our Christian testimo-
nes--and the prosperity of Truth, so far as
il IS connected with our labors, we believe,
very much depend upon the early adoption
of this measure.


We therefore, under solemn and weigh





and with arden. desires that all our move
mepts may be under the guidance of Him,
who only can lead us in safety, have agreed
to propose fol your consideration, the pro-
priety and expedency Of holding Yearly
Meeting for Friends in unity with US. resid-
ing within the limits of those Quarterly
Meetings, heretofore represented in the
Iearly Meeting held in Philadelphia; for
~ IN IA ed
Quarterly and Monthly Meetings, which
may be prepared for such measure, sheutl
appoint Representatives to meet in Phila-
delphia, on the third secend-day in the
tenth mouth next, at ten O'Clock in the
morning, in company with other members
favorable to our views, there to hold Year
~ Meeting of men and women Friends, up
on the principles oi the early professors of
our name, and tor the same purposes that
brought them together in a religious capac.
ty-to exaIt the standard Of Truth--pro-
mote righteousness and peace in tile earth
edify the churches--and generally to attend
to all such concerns as relate to the welfare
Of religious society. and the cause of our ho-
! ly Rcdccmer. who is God over all, blessed
/ forever, Amen.


| Signed by direction and on behalf of tho
meeting by


Stephen Stephens. John Mann,

stephen Long, Isaac Kay,


Richard barnard, Edward Garrigues.

MRS. Ciarissa Iler died in Neville, anoet
80 miles from the city of Cincinnati, on the
18th April. Her death was supposedto De
caused by fright As she was sitting at
home in the evening, a young man impru-
IDENTIFY wrapped himself in white sheet
and came into the house. Mrs. Her beng
in delicate state of health, the fright
brought on an illness, from which she never
recovered

.NrTy Gold Mne.--A letter now before US
from Taxahaw, Lancaster District, dated
23d ult. states that the richest gold mine in
the Southern States has lately been discov-
cred in the neghbourhood of that place.
Seven hands from N Carolina are now en-
ployed in the mine. The prospect is highly
promising and our correspondent says -
Before long you will see our Lancaster
farmers coming to market with gold instead
Of cotton;"--hepe some of our subscribers
live near this place CherasV Shec.

Nothing is talked of at Frankfort, but the
will Of the late Mr.. Bethmann, who has left
fortune of twenty million of francs Dur
ing the whole course of his life he was ex-
tremely successful and yet his widow is in
situation difficult to be described. BY this
will Mrs. Bcthmann receives only an annuity
sufficient for her support, while lady to
whom the banker was attached is provided
for like the mistress of a Prince. The wid-
ow, by this will, is to leave the house of her
husband, within year, to renounce all right
to the education of her children, and to give
up, as part of her entaled estate, all her
Jewels and valuable effects.-BruSSeis Pa.

"Corona or WliO,-The most luminous phc-

OF the prsmatic colors, nearly as bright as in the
rainbow,ln which red and yellow were prcdonn-
ant The outer or largest circle was about sixty de-
grees in diameter, the colors in which were not
so brilliant as those in the smaller one, and re-
sembled the pale fame of candle. The third or
middle one, was barely visible. The uncom-
mon b!illlancy of those Coronas, together with
the appearance of three at the same time, cir
cumstance not recollected by many to have hap
pened before alarmed several who had never read
or thought much on the causes which produce
the rainbow, or on the various phenomena pro.
dnced by the reflection and refraction of LIGHT.
Many were OF the opinion that it was ominous of
some extraordinary event about to happen. con.
sequently inquiries were made of the aged and


learned, the probable cause Of this uncommon
appearance"

"Fatai Revenge. "A man by the name
OF Prlce, has been convicted in Sussex coun-
ty, N. j. OF the crime of arson, for burning
the barn of Mr.. Nicholas Ryerson, last win.
ter. He was sentenced to undergo ten wears
imprisonment. Upwards of eighty witnesses
were examined, and the trial occupied the
better part of five days. Price is man Of
handsome fortune, and was led to the com
mission of the crime Of which he has been
convicted by a spirit of revenge
